dialogues.text: Do we belong there... Do we not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MAN'S FACE... thousand-mile stare... sweat trickling from his temples... (This is FERRIS)

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN, (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: SOMEWHERE ELSE 2A
dialogues.text: Hands wind tape around the grip of a cricket bat.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter what I think. The bat slices THROUGH FRAME striking someone 0O.S.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: But the man’s face here doesn’t grimace.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We're there and we're tired and can’t see the end. We can’t even console ourselves thinking they’re just as tired because they’re not. It’s a fallacy that prolonged war weakens the enemy. It weeds out the weak. It makes the enemy stronger. FERRIS drinks an orange soda as flies copulate on a torn window screen in his monastic room. INT. HOFFMAN’S TOWNHOUSE (VIRGINIA) - NIGHT 2B A dark figure stares at a plasma screen. HOFFMAN. Breaking news on CNN (silent). (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2c CHATTER 9/21/07 -- PINK 2.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: HOFFMAN is talking with a headset on and as he talks his words are recorded in type.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: You can’t make a war go away. Like a child ‘hiding’ in a corner with his hands over his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO FERRIS
dialogues.text: FERRIS is in his thirties. Neither shaven nor unshaven. He could be a Madrassa student, an Islamic convert, but isn’t. He’s been in the desert too long. In his own kind of war too long. Numb.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We pulled out of Vietnam and a million people who had believed in us were murdered. Was that really giving peace a chance? Or were we just being selfish pricks who couldn’t be bothered. A FAN oscillating on a broken table. Cell phones charging in a power strip. Extra batteries -- lots of extra batteries -- you don’t want to be without your phone. Water bottle, wristwatch ticking, pint of Johnny Walker Black. .45 micro-compact, six extra clips.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And Vietnam was a little colonial war... INT. HOFFMAN'S TOWNSHOUSE (VIRGINIA) - NIGHT 2c As HOFFMAN, insomniac, turns away from kettle, water, etc, with his headset and coffee...

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: This is what you call a global conflagration.

dialogues.speaker: A BLISTERING COLLAGE OF NEW FOOTAGE 3

The shadow of a jet slamming into one of the Trade Towers. THEO VAN GOGH lying dead in his blood on a Dutch street. Flashes of masked kidnappers on Al-Khaleej Network. And over this

dialogues.speaker: ON SOUND
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: A corresponding AURAL COLLAGE you might get from a random sampling of radio-waves and NSA wiretaps if you were George Martin... Bits of English, media Arabic, intelligence “chatter,” static, building up to a howl which cuts off abruptly as we OPEN UP ON:

dialogues.text: The STREET: THE ENTIRE ROW OF HOUSES is obliterated. It's a bomb big enough to blow out windows for miles. We

dialogues.text: INT. FERRIS’ ROOM IN SAMARRA - CONTINUOUS ACTION - MORNIN The MANCHESTER EXPLOSION plays behind FERRIS on TV as he blows dust from dismantled gun parts, wipes them with an oiled rag, methodical, yet weary...

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Despite this new operational intensity, the new threat is not what they do, but how they do it.

dialogues.speaker: CCTV IMAGES
dialogues.text: The MILK VAN rounds the park, and pulls to the curb in front of a central office of an international bank. Shot static. A PAKISTANI MAN gets out and the CCTV stop- motions him around the corner. INT. HOFFMAN’S STUDY (VIRGINIA) - NIGHT 10

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The mystery is their command and control. How they communicate. How they secure their networks... HOFFMAN -- fifties, a lifer CIA officer, flawed, too smart to be “professional,” too professional to be as smart in the end as he needs to be, a little bit of a miles gloriosus but aware of it, a truth-teller and liar and inhabitant of the wilderness of mirrors -- moves through darkened rooms, dictation headset on, his words coming up on a computer screen.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: The enemy has figured out they’re fighting guys from the future. If you live in the past, behave like it’s the past and guys from the future can’t see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSLIM MEN stand pinched with cold on a street corner in Turkish Germany, angry, conspiring, looking around for police. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Elsewhere, box codes with Arabic characters being written; a jihadist getting his coded orders from behind a loose brick.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: This is the new AQ. ON HOFFMAN as he looks instead out chill blue panes at a freak Virginia snow falling on his garden below.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: What I need you to understand, sir, whatever the fuck I call you... Delete clause... “Whatever the fuck I call you” disappears from the screen.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Continue dictation... is this, colon: These people don’t want to negotiate. They want the Universal Caliphate established across the face of the earth and every infidel converted or dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOFFMAN, in a hard chair, looking at a figure we assume to be the President, 0.S. Others also 0.S. We are only ON Hoffman. (NOTE: Shoot this dialogue both in Hoffman’s townhouse and in the Oval Office to intercut.)

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Terrorism -- or ‘Tourism’ as we say back at home -- is easy. Remember the Virginia sniper? A kid and his stepfather with one rifle fired from the trunk of their car paralyzed an entire state for a month. Imagine what I could do with ten rifles. Or fifty. One in every state opening fire on the Prophet's birthday and I could destroy the US economy for a few thousand dollars in bullets and bus tickets.  14 15 16 17 18 CHATTER 9/21/07 -- PINK 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOFFMAN in the snow-light, outside on his blue-lit GARDEN PORCH. He switches on the light to his garden. We see a large treed area giving onto a small dock with a small motor yacht.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What’s happened, is that the other guy knows it’s easy, too.

dialogues.speaker: BRIEF IMAGE 15
dialogues.text: OF THE MILK VAN, the stop-motion PAKISTANI.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The end of our world is easier than you think.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE OVAL OFFICE 16
dialogues.text: Hoffman with his black shoes together, just sitting, finished...

dialogues.speaker: COLLAGE OF IMAGES 17
dialogues.text: And as the NSA CHATTER rebuilds on SOUND, rising to an Abbey Road crescendo... we see images of every event in this war from 9/11 to the present... and the instant the aural/visual collage reaches its limit and goes to sudden silence --

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: The old TV in the corner shows silent images from the Manchester bombing, a jihadist statement, the continual news stream. FERRIS lights a cigarette with a Bic, rakes the curtains aside, looks out the window, knowing all he'll see are the ruins of Golden Dome and the same street life as yesterday. ON his face:

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Tell me something real.

dialogues.speaker: BASSAM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (no Arab accent, perfect American English) All I got is real. EXT. STREET - (SAMARRA) -— DAY 20 A GREEN RENAULT moving through the streets of Samarra. FLASHBACK - EXT. BASSAM’S APARTMENT - BALCONY 21 To BASSAM and FERRIS talking, drinking beer on BASSAM’S APARTMENT balcony last night. Bassam’s wife and 2-year- old son can be seen behind them inside, preparing food.

dialogues.speaker: BASSAM
dialogues.text: A guy named Nizar, from Aquiz up near Tikrit. I knew him when I was a kid before I left. He wanted to come to America with me but he couldn’t get the papers. INTERCUT FERRIS packing up his “Go” bag in his room.

dialogues.speaker: BASSAM
dialogues.text: He got all messed up in the head after the invasion, you know, started working with the Baathists -.. then the jihadists. But he’s scared shitless now, man. He’s supposed to do a martyrdom operation, but he doesn’t want to die. So he’s coming to us. INT. FERRIS’ ROOM 22 FERRIS, alone in his room, packed, stares dully at the TV images. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 22 23 CHATTER 9/21/07 -- PINK 8.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He knows about the UK bombings?

dialogues.speaker: BASSAM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He knows all the fuck about everything. He says. FERRIS looks around the room. If he never comes back to it, so what: a couple of pairs of socks and underwear on a shelf. Empty booze bottles. Stack of books. FERRIS leaves the room. Closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FERRIS, driving the GREEN RENAULT, which looks like it has served as a taxi for a thousand years in the desert. Arab beads dangle from the rearview mirror. A news broadcast in Arabic is on. Ferris turns it up. Whatever it says (it is about the Manchester bombings), disturbs him as he drives through the crowded streets. Every young man visible through the dusty windshield and side-windows is his potential murderer. Dangerous men looking at his car. FERRIS slows at an intersection with a traffic cop, leans over to unlock the door for -- waiting at a street cafe -- BASSAM, an Iraqi-American hipster under considerable strain.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Ya, Bassam. Marhaba. BASSAM slides onto the passenger seat: Cheap leather jacket, gelled hair, an Iraqi by way of Detroit. Ferris pulls the car back into the street traffic.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Rules of the day. If the car’s immobilized, start shooting. No one gets traded. Everybody dies.

dialogues.speaker: BASSAM
dialogues.text: So, same as every day... They slow at the exit from the city. An arched gate through the walls. An ELDERLY WOMAN selling flowers holds out a yellow blossom. Ferris says no, then makes a salaam to a mystified SOLDIER who doesn’t quite understand why his OFFICER (hauling him off by an equipment strap) is indicating “leave the CIA guys alone” as other SOLDIERS check vehicles. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 23 24 CHATTER 9/21/07 -- PINK 9.

dialogues.speaker: BASSAM
dialogues.text: We’re going to get killed by one of those fuckers. That’s my prediction.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: We’re going to get killed by somebody. The American presence fades in the rearview mirror.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: What are the chances your buddy’s playing both sides?

dialogues.speaker: BASSAM
dialogues.text: I don’t know. What are they with me? FERRIS smiles at him. But you never know. Looks out at men at a cafe staring at him as he passes. Cigarettes. Cheap shoes. Poverty, heat, dust, despair, anger. As we go through the slums past groups of ashamed unemployed fathers in plastic sandals and rescue-mission clothes, BASSAM texts on a cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: BASSAM
dialogues.text: I say it again: We had more fucking green cards we wouldn’t be in this shit. We’d all be in Beverly Hills. From the craziness of the SOUK --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long dirt road cutting across white hot desert. The GREEN RENAULT moving through dust on the road leading to what once was a farm: a villa with outbuildings, broken irrigation equipment, blowing dust. It might once have been as nice as something in Andalusia. Now it’s a wreck. FERRIS has a folding carbine across his lap now as he drives, staring towards the house. BASSAM still on texting.

dialogues.speaker: BASSAM
dialogues.text: He says one of us has to come in. Come up to the house. Ferris just looks at Bassam who’s sweating. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BASSAM
dialogues.text: He means me, he means me. He wants to see my face before he comes out.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: And what do you think of that?

dialogues.speaker: BASSAM
dialogues.text: They'd have to be smarter than I think they are for it to be a setup... but it still could be a setup. Ferris parks. Bassam doesn’t get out. Ferris doesn’t rush him. Eventually --

dialogues.speaker: BASSAM
dialogues.text: I’m not getting my head cut off on the Internet, sahib. You’1l shoot me, right?

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Fuck that, I’1l shoot you right now. You got that thing on mute? With a fuck-you look, Bassam clicks back in on his call -

dialogues.speaker: BASSAM
dialogues.text: Ya, Nizar... (etc., etc.)

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: (while Bassam talks) We don’t go into the house. Bring him out, no matter what he says. I‘1l cover you from the small building. Tell him he’ll come out to us if he wants to talk. (as Bassam’s hesitating too long now) Do the fuck what I said. Bassam gets out, starts to walk towards the main house. FERRIS gets out and, as he glances at the sky: BIRD’S-EYE VIEW - MOVING 25 We see the farm, the car, Bassam moving toward the house, Ferris, everything, startlingly clear from high above.  26 27 28 CHATTER 9/21/07 -- PINK 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As FERRIS heads to the SMALL BUILDING for better vision and protection, he sees the silver glint high in the sky (a Predator). He speed-dials a number --

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: (anxiously into phone) Who’s on? I need you out of here, right now. They’1l know an agent’s under it. Get it out of here now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ARMY INTEL SGT. glances 0.S. to an implied Predator operator and nods “OK”... A CIA TECHNICIAN in a headset somewhere in Virginia moves a JOYSTICK, and we see the CAMERA IMAGE of the VILLA sweep away as the Predator turns away from it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks like the shed where Saddam clambered out of his spider-hole to fry eggs. As FERRIS finishes clearing the rooms, one of his cell phones vibrates. Answers:

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: I can’t talk now, Larry --

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: his feet up, undoing his tie as if he’s had a terrible few hours.

dialogues.speaker: ATTORNEY
dialogues.text: (on phone) She wants the house.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: She can have it.

dialogues.speaker: PREDATOR GUYS
dialogues.text: listening and grinning. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 28 29 CHATTER 9/21/07 -- PINK 12.

dialogues.speaker: ATTORNEY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (on phone) No, she can’t. I’m not gonna let you give her the house. She can ask for whatever she wants but I’m not listening.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Then why are you calling? Ferris hangs up. Shuts off the phone like he should've done before. Unlimbers a serious next-generation HK with optics and a long barrel. Peers through an aperture -- FERRIS’ POV scanning for danger, then back to the main house where Bassam is coming out with another Iraqi -- NIZAR -- a former academic, with that self-possession, but maybe a little crazy, with fear, at least.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FERRIS and NIZAR sit looking at each other in the gloom. BASSAM leans against a wall of the thrashed room, holding Ferris’ HK. NIZAR is terrified, fingertips pressed together trembling, staring at FERRIS for help.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Maybe I can help you.

dialogues.speaker: NIZAR
dialogues.text: Thanks God, thanks God.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: But why do you need help?

dialogues.speaker: NIZAR
dialogues.text: I know too many things. They prepared me to go outside Iraq.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Tell me what you mean by ‘outside Iraq.’

dialogues.speaker: NIZAR
dialogues.text: But then they said they needed me for martyrdom, here in Iraq. When a man knows too much they say ‘martyrdom.’

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Who are ‘they,’ Nizar? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NIZAR
dialogues.text: (in good English) I don’t want to die. I want to go to America.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Then you did well to call Bassam.

dialogues.speaker: NIZAR
dialogues.text: God, God, God. Thanks God.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: But you have to tell me what you know. Who are ‘they’?

dialogues.speaker: NIZAR
dialogues.text: I have a Ph.D. Me. And they want me to blow myself up!

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Ph.D. in what? Chemistry? What do you know about radiological materials, Nizar?

dialogues.speaker: NIZAR
dialogues.text: No! Linguistics! I speak five languages. Five. No one should say ‘martyr’ to me.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: You're a rare flower.

dialogues.speaker: NIZAR
dialogues.text: I am!

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: You don’t want to kill the Jews and Crusaders. Nizar won't go that far. Says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: So why come to me?

dialogues.speaker: NIZAR
dialogues.text: If I know enough to be martyred, with you I know enough to stay alive.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Maybe. FERRIS turns away from NIZAR and lights a cigarette, playing disinterested, and knowing very well what he’s doing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: NIZAR takes out a DVD from a folded dirty envelope. (Perhaps play this 0.S.)

dialogues.speaker: NIZAR
dialogues.text: Do you have a computer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOFFMAN, bowl of cornflakes in hand, contemplates his small yacht. A line on his phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. VILLA/INT. FERRIS’ PARKED RENAULT 31 A LAPTOP SCREEN: a video of a man sitting on a prayer rug in a nondescript room.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: I got an Iraqi walk-in, up near Samarra. He’s got a communique video somebody walked across the Iranian border. I’m watching it. It’s Al-Saleem.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Can you see his face? HOFFMAN walking back to his house.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Yes. I’m looking at the white whale, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: What’s he saying?

dialogues.speaker: BACK WITH FERRIS
dialogues.text: The man in the video speaking in Arabic to the camera.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Well, it must be current. He mentions the Sheffield bus bombs a week ago... He’s telling the brothers to prepare for UK operations already planned. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That would be about the bombing his people fucked up in Manchester this morning. (translating) We will avenge the America Wars on the Muslim world. We will come at them everywhere. We will strike at random, across Europe and then America, continually. We have bled. Now they will bleed. And bleed. Until they are bled out.

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK TO
dialogues.text: EXT. HOFFMAN’S PORCH (VIRGINIA) - PREDAWN 32 HOFFMAN'S WIFE looks fuzzy-brained, fuzzy pink robe and slippers from the house porch. She goes.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN'S WIFE
dialogues.text: It's 4 A.M., what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Saving civilization. (sotto) Shut the fuck up. HOFFMAN enters the house.

dialogues.speaker: BACK WITH FERRIS 33
dialogues.text: We see Al-

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: The disks are passed from hand to hand. The communiques are not transmitted, not copied. Nizar says real orders are verbal, or in code, on paper. (backing up video) At the end he repeats five words. A code... Saleem CLOSE saying the Arabic nouns for “Mountain,” “Razor,” “Fruit,” “One,” “Seven.”

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Any indication where he is?

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Maybe. My guy, Nizar, hasn’t got his location, but there’s shitty raised-print Victorian wallpaper --. anaglypta... he’s maybe in England... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 33 34 CHATTER 9/21/07 -- PINK 16.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Have Bassam upload the fucker now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOFFMAN pours coffee then encounters a sleep-walking young son and steers him to the toilet.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: They're killing anyone who knows anything. He’s scared. We need to debrief him very carefully.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: So do it.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: In the States.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: I think he has a lot more, Ed...

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: He doesn’t. Milk him now, on site, and cut him loose.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: They’re already on to him. That's why he’s running. HOFFMAN angles his young son’s shoulders to keep him from peeing on the floor in his sleep --

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: He wants to go to the US in one piece rather than to Paradise ina hundred? He should’ve thought of that before. Fuck him.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: They will, Ed. They'll kill him.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: All right and if they do, we can see who pulls the trigger. Am I missing the point? (to his son) Night night, Timmy, Dada’s working. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 34 35 CHATTER 9/21/07 -- PINK 17.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Ferris) He’s the enemy. He deserves nothing.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: I already offered him asylum.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: You lied. And not for the first time. Put him back on the street.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO FERRIS 35
dialogues.text: doesn’t like it, but he knows it’s right. THROUGH the dirty window he sees -- NIZAR, out in the sun, hint of a relieved smile on his face, taking a cigarette from BASSAM. FERRIS hangs up and pockets the phone. Walks outside.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Nizar. I have a few more questions.

dialogues.speaker: NIZAR
dialogues.text: No more questions here. Take me to the Green Zone. FERRIS says nothing... and Nizar’s hopeful smile fades.

dialogues.speaker: NIZAR
dialogues.text: But they will kill me. Still nothing from FERRIS. NIZAR attacks him. FERRIS hurls him onto the dirt, then slams him into a wall as he rises. Nizar starts laughing and crying at once.

dialogues.speaker: NIZAR
dialogues.text: You want to see who kills me. I talk to you and that’s all you want. I don’t want to die.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: It's worse, Nizar. You’ve seen my face. You know what that means.

dialogues.speaker: NIZAR
dialogues.text: Guantanamo? You threaten me with Guantanamo? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Nizar spits. That’s what he thinks about Guantanamo.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: (Arabic) No. If you don’t do what I say, I’‘1l execute you right here. Give me your phone. Nizar stares at him. Then does as he’s told. Ferris hands the phone to BASSAM, the sparks of the operation, who inspects the bottom of the phone, finds the right connector in his kit, and connects it to his laptop. Bassam hacks the phone.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, we'll be watching you. Protecting you.

dialogues.speaker: NIZAR
dialogues.text: (laughs painfully) You can’t even protect yourselves!

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Tell me everything or you get nothing.

dialogues.speaker: LAPTOP SCREEN
dialogues.text: as information uploads from Nizar’s phone. EXT. SAMARRA —- MORNING 36 NIZAR, hollow-eyed, comes out of a mosque courtyard, pushing his moped, and moves through the thronged street.

dialogues.speaker: BASSAM
dialogues.text: They're already on him. BASSAM, looking like an ordinary unemployed Iraqi, plug of his cell in his ear, is in position at a cafe. Ferris on the opposite side of the street. Both see hard-faced guys monitoring Bassam.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: I see them.

dialogues.speaker: FROM ABOVE
dialogues.text: The narrow street in deep, complicated shadow.  38 39 CHATTER 9/21/07 -- PINK 19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOFFMAN is watching on a monitor. NIZAR goes into shadow.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Why they can’t do this shit at noon is what I want to know... EXT. SAMARRA — DAY 39 The AQ guys are moving through the roof. Another is watching as NIZAR puts his bike on its kickstand and goes to a kiosk cut in a hovel and comes out unwrapping cigarettes. He puts one in his mouth and lights it and starts pushing his bike again. The AQ GUYS pick up the pace to intercept him. Into his phone mic --

dialogues.speaker: BASSAM
dialogues.text: I can’t move. They’1ll see me. Too many guys watching for just such an action, Bassam stays glued to the spot, watching the inevitable. FERRIS, too, watches NIZAR, hating himself... And now, NIZAR sees the men approaching him, one with an AK wrapped in a towel. NIZAR runs, pulling a pistol, a terrible weapon with a taped handle. As he turns to defend himself, the guys, shouting, open fire massively, with horrific civilian casualties... NIZAR, hit deliberately in the legs, falls into the dust along with his pistol. As he reaches for it, it’s snatched away... BASSAM stares. An IRAQI ARMY ARMORED VEHICLE is trying to come through the crowd 50-yards away, blowing a klaxon... FERRIS fights through the crowd toward NIZAR who's lying on the ground, still alive. As he’s picked up like a doll -- legs broken, calling for help, struggling -- and lifted toward the back of an open Jeep, Bassam intercepts Ferris, drags at him. Sotto voce, Arabic:

dialogues.speaker: BASSAM
dialogues.text: Boss, we gotta go. We lost him. We gotta go, man, we gotta go. FERRIS looks towards the Iraqi armored vehicle, coming closer. Looks around at the crowd: no one watching him. Everyone running. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: FERRIS fades back into a deep doorway, takes out his pistol, waits for the gap, and at thirty feet, fires through the chaos, hitting NIZAR in the head, and the gap in the crowd closes... FERRIS and BASSAM move slowly down an alley, then run...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad PREDATOR CAM pictures of this event: All either in shadows or chaos. They can barely tell what happened. TECHNICIANS pulling up less-than-useful images of the hit squad, the car they pile into, the car driving away. On another screen, a download of Nizar’s AL-SALEEM DVD replays. Translators (serious young men) watch, writing on pads, arguing about a word.

dialogues.speaker: TRANSLATORS
dialogues.text: He said ‘kelba.’/ No, he didn’t, (etc. ) Into his Bluetooth headset --

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: I executed him.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: You did, and if you hadn’t, he’d be describing you down to your eyebrows to them right now. He was going to get killed no matter what he did. You know, we all fuckin’ die. Older I get I’m convinced it doesn’t matter how. I’m fucked, you’re fucked, he’s fucked, everybody’s fucked. He’s just the one who was fucked today. And he was dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. BASSAM’S APARTMENT —- BALCONY 4l FERRIS, sweaty, dirty, on the balcony of BASSAM’'S APARTMENT. Bassam sits near him, shook up. Nothing from Ferris. Behind him in the apartment BASSAM’S WIFE feeds the baby, unaware of any drama. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Is your silence supposed to say something? This is war. Your pal, who I guess you had some kind of intense cross-cultural eye- contact with, was a terrorist a- hole who at his apex, was a coward who wanted to go to Disneyland.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: I’m going north now.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: You’re going nowhere. You’re blown. There’s chatter...

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: If I’m blown, Ed, they’re going to be destroying the safehouse. You should have sent a team there the minute Nizar was shot. You didn’t send one, did you? FERRIS hangs up. He looks fiercely at BASSAM.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Not since we’ve been talking. Ferris?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FERRIS, atop a ridgeline, peers through binoculars at: A HOUSE in the middle distance, like a fortified villa. Some outbuildings, dead vehicles. A small fire burning behind a kitchen door where a rifle-slung man tips things into it: disks, notebooks, papers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man at the fire looks up at a djellabah-clad figure walking down the hill toward him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: (in Arabic) Friend. I need help. The man at the fire unshoulders his rifle and yells at the robed figure to stop. FERRIS keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: (in Arabic) My car broke down on the road just there. Another armed man carrying a box of cell phones to be destroyed comes out the kitchen doorway and Ferris has to do it now: Pulls a pistol from under his djellabah and shoots the first man, then the one with the box as he drops it and unslings his rifle --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BASSAM, hearing the distant shots, peers through binoculars at Ferris running toward the fire. Into his Bluetooth --

dialogues.speaker: BASSAM
dialogues.text: Urgent request you dispatch Chili, Speck, or Nitrate to these coordinates. (gives them) This is a live target, a known operating base of an Al-Saleem cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Real-time images from the three Predators covering Iraq. A YOUNG SERGEANT wearing a headset moves a joystick. Latitude and longitude numbers alter. A CAPTAIN watches.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: (AD-LIBS )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High value target...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second man shot crawls back into the buildings, legs not working, as a now-frantic FERRIS arrives and kicks at the stuff burning in the fire: cell phones, digital cameras, memory sticks -- then turns to the kitchen door and goes in --  46 47 48 CHATTER 9/21/07 -- PINK 23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man has died in the filthy kitchen. Flies are already finding his blood, which is all over the tiles. FERRIS moves past him into the living area. Mattresses, a wretched TV, pile of porn tapes. He finds a bunch of phones, SIM cards, flashdrives in a shoebox. As he claws them into his pockets, he turns to see an unarmed BOY in the doorway. Some sort of servant of the jihadists. Infected sore at the corner of his mouth. FERRIS is aiming the carbine at him.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: (in Arabic) Get out. The boy scrambles out. Ferris moves into another room, and sees:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MAN FROZEN IN PLACE, gun in hand, not raised, above a trip line leading to a nail bomb not completely concealed under a blanket. FERRIS rips him with an automatic burst, then spins in to cover behind the wall as the MAN falls across the trip-wire. An explosion of shrapnel rocks the place, blowing holes in the cinder-blocks. FERRIS, head ringing, choking on dust, scrambles to scrape more SIM cards off a table, looks through a window and sees two cars churning up the dust, heading for the house, and BASSAM driving up by the kitchen door. FERRIS grabs a few more things near the fire, shoves them into a plastic grocery bag, and jumps into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BASSAM hits the gas. The car races up the rutted road, the chase car after them. Ahead, FERRIS sees: A YELLOW CHEVY, waiting on the shoulder of the main road. FERRIS takes out his pistol, cocks it, holds it in his lap. They are nearing the intersection.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Turn! As the RENAULT speeds past, FERRIS shoots the driver of the YELLOW CHEVY, blowing out the Chevy’s window.  49 50 51 52 CHATTER 9/21/07 -- PINK 24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RENAULT bursts onto the road, barely missing a DUMP TRUCK, which, for its part, intersects with a burst of automatic fire meant for the RENAULT. BASSAM straightens out... FERRIS has bought time as the Chevy's bloody driver is replaced. The CHEVY gives chase again, followed by the other CHASE CAR, bursting from the dirt road. With a very brief lead, FERRIS is on the phone...

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: We are in some serious fucking trouble here on Highway 1. We are south of Samarra, a green Renault, being pursued by two cars. The lead chase car is a yellow Chevy. I’ve got all sorts of critical intel in the vehicle... Ferris sees in the side mirror: A man aiming an RPG out the windshield-less CHEVY --

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Get around them! The cars in front of them. BASSAM swerves, trying to get past on the shoulder, but it’s no good. The Chevy closes -- Bassam’s car slides, and the RPG is fired --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ROCKET broadsides the Renault’s driver’s side door. The windows implode, FERRIS’ face and T-shirt splashed with blood, peppered with shrapnel. Bassam, taking the full impact of the blast is... gone... blown apart -- there’s no one where he just was driving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FERRIS grabs at the steering wheel, but his hand slips on the blood covering it, and the car somersaults across an irrigation ditch and into the desert, flipping onto its roof, huge volumes of dirt plowing into the interior of the shattered car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BLACKHAWK comes up over the ridgeline, orients itself, and fires a CANNON, blowing the Chevy to pieces, shrapnel hitting the second chase car --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FERRIS lies upside down, held by the seat belt, lacerated with bits of shrapnel and glass, blood trickling, covered with dirt, trying to reach for his dropped pistol... ON SOUND WE HEAR: HELICOPTER ROTORS. EXT. ROAD NEAR JIHADIST’S VILLA - DAY 55 The second car and armed men trying to get out of it are torn to pieces by another CANNON from the BLACKHAWK. It then wheels and finishes off the YELLOW CHEVY. EXT. ROAD NEAR JIHADIST’S VILLA - DAY 56 A SECOND BLACKHAWK lands a SPECIAL FORCES TEAM which instantly sets up a perimeter, while a MEDIC heads for the car, his HELMETED HEAD appearing at FERRIS’ window.

dialogues.speaker: MEDIC
dialogues.text: Can you hear me? Sir? Sir? Only barely. The voice is muffled and FERRIS can’t answer. Dangling upside down, he stares at the bloodied driver's seat where Bassam used to be.

dialogues.speaker: MEDIC
dialogues.text: Let's get him out, out, out. FERRIS is dragged out. Rushed to the chopper through the swirling dust as the second BLACKHAWK keeps circling above. As they lay him inside, he closes his eyes... A trill of Arab music, distorting, hallucinatory, opiated...

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 57
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HALLUCINATION 58
dialogues.text: AN ELDERLY IRAQI WOMAN holds out a YELLOW BLOSSOM and is obliterated by an explosion. The cricket bat with flecks of blood on it. It slices down again, striking someone

dialogues.speaker: O.S. --
dialogues.text: INT. US BASE (QATAR) —- EMERGENCY BAY - DAY 59 FERRIS’ hearing is shot. Everything muffled as he stares up at a figure silhouetted against bright lights --

dialogues.speaker: TWO VOICES
dialogues.text: What is your name? The figure is either a doctor or a torturer; Ferris can’t be sure which.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR/TORTURER
dialogues.text: Do you know where you are? The figure plucks pieces of shrapnel out of Ferris’ face, neck, arms and chest with surgical tweezers. Some, when they’re dropped on a tray, make a metallic clink, but most do not: the ones that are white and splintered.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Bone fragments... Not yours. Not Ferris’. Bassam’s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ferris’ wounds have been cleaned and dressed. He’s not that bad off considering, sitting outside a barracks with a Coke, watching a guy approach with a cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Where’s the stuff I had?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: All uploaded to Langley. (hands Ferris the phone) Hoffman. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 60 61 CHATTER 9/21/07 -- PINK 27.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ferris? Christmas came early, buddy. FERRIS is barely capable of speaking to Hoffman.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: (hating Hoffman) What'd I get for Christmas, Ed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoffman is looking at RECENT SURVEILLANCE PICTURES of a safehouse in a lively lower-middle class neighborhood in Amman.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: A safehouse in Amman, among other things. Jihadists coming and going like it’s a student hostel. Look at this fuckin’ place. PHOTOS of men going in and coming out. Playing dominos at a cafe. No beards or any other sign they are anything other than secular students. But they aren’t. Hoffman intently regards one photo like he vaguely recognizes someone (MUSTAFA KARAMI). The Al-Saleem DVD plays silently on another screen.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: What are you doing for Bassam’s family?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: I didn’t know him. What are you doing for Bassam’s family? He was your guy. Ferris unable to listen to this hangs up the phone and hands it back to the other agent. Two seconds later it rings again and the guy hands it back to Ferris. Hoffman continues as if Ferris hadn’t hung up on him --

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: You’re going to Amman as Acting Station Chief. You’1ll outrank Holiday. You’re the show-runner. Ferris sees a sliver of bone the Doctor missed in his arm and pulls it out. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 61 62 CHATTER 9/21/07 -- PINK 28.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: You'll liaise with Jordanian GID, who are as hot for Al-Saleem as we are, working with a man named Hani Salaam, who is not your usual raghead fingernail-puller. Hani’s a pro.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Am I sharing information with him?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Let me say this about that: No. You want to take a few weeks off, bang the wife?

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: I’m getting a divorce, Ed, you know that. You know more about it than I do.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: So you'll go to Amman? FERRIS digs a small hole in the dust, puts the bone fragment in, and covers it.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: I’1l go to Amman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BASSAM’S WIFE, in mourning clothes, sits with Ferris, her 2-year-old daughter asleep in a stroller next to her. In Arabic, subtitled, resigned to these facts:

dialogues.speaker: BASSAM'S WIFE
dialogues.text: There can be no funeral. No burial. No cleansing of the body... because there is no body. Ferris nods; he knows this is the way it is with Muslim death rites. Awkward silence before -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: I want to help.

dialogues.speaker: BASSAM'S WIFE
dialogues.text: What can anyone do? There’s one thing perhaps: Ferris sets an envelope on the table that is thick with cash, and Bassam’s Wife is suddenly very nervous --

dialogues.speaker: BASSAM'S WIFE
dialogues.text: No, no, no --

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Please take it. I’m sorry it’s not more. (as she’s looking around anxiously) No one’s watching. No one will know where it came from. Don’t be afraid. But she is afraid, whether anyone is watching or not. Ferris tries to push the envelope closer to her, but she gets up, terrified of him, and hurries away, pushing the stroller, leaving him alone at the table...

dialogues.speaker: DAY 64
dialogues.text: Ferris is sitting shotgun with Arab-American kid from the Embassy in an old diesel Mercedes, suitcase in back. FERRIS awkwardly ices his knee, in pain.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: We can’t afford better than this?

dialogues.speaker: SKIP
dialogues.text: I brought this car in case you wanted to cruise the safehouse before.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: No one ‘cruises’ that safehouse! What I want is a shave and a clean shirt. Where’s my apartment?

dialogues.speaker: SKIP
dialogues.text: You’re in a high-rise. Hot and cold water, plus you can drink it. Not much local color though. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 64A
dialogues.text: 65 66 CHATTER 9/21/07 -- PINK 30.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: I’ve had it with local color.

dialogues.speaker: SKIP
dialogues.text: Exterminate the brutes? FERRIS looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: I’m glad you're literate. But you’re not very bright. Unless that’s embassy security we have a GID tail. Or worse. Still want to ‘cruise’ the safehouse? Behind them, a black SUV follows. SKIP looks alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Just fuckin’ drive. INT. FERRIS’ APARTMENT (AMMAN) - DAY 64A FERRIS looks through the gleaming, modern, well-furnished apartment. Alienated. He plugs in his BlackBerry. The instant it gets coverage, it rings. The name comes up on the screen: GRETCHEN. He presses “Ignore,” and the ringing stops. He goes and looks at himself in the mirror. Begins to shave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little fortress in the Abdoun neighborhood, guarded by US MARINES and JORDANIAN SPECIAL FORCES. Sandbagged and ringed by troops and protesters, it looks like the embassy of a nation under siege, which is what it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the “MEDIA WALL,” A BARRAGE OF SURVEILLANCE IMAGES of the SAFEHOUSE. Arabs coming and going. Wary men in sunglasses. Things being carried in. Carried out. A sequence of one man walking from safehouse to mosque. No particular individual seen twice.

dialogues.speaker: HOLIDAY
dialogues.text: NSA is listening to all the phones and computer links of anyone who's been near the house... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ferris, clean-shaven, clean clothes, stands with HOLIDAY, the nominal head of station, twice Ferris’ age.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: That's over with. It doesn’t happen that way anymore. They might as well be listening to a seashell. (beat) You don’t have to be a genius to stop using telephones and email when you’re up against the NSA. But you do have to be pretty stupid not to have noticed they don’t communicate electronically anymore.

dialogues.speaker: HOLIDAY
dialogues.text: (holding his temper) The house is owned by a family named Alousi. In my opinion, it just seems like a normal Jordanian family with a lot of country relatives...

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah, and all of them unmarried men between 18 and 35.

dialogues.speaker: HOLIDAY
dialogues.text: Whatever information you got in Iraq, I just don’t think this house is what you think it is. The young men in this house drink alcohol.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: So did Mohammed Atta. It’s Takfir methodology. They shave their beards, they drink liquor, they stuff dollar bills into g-strings. Got it? It’s permitted, to deceive the infidel. (using a remote to scan digital pics) You’ve got the guys going in and going out but who’s following them when they leave?

dialogues.speaker: HOLIDAY
dialogues.text: There’s so much activity at this... location... that we... we've exhausted the station’s... indigenous-appearing manpower. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 66 CHATTER 9/21/07 -- PINK 32.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: FERRIS leans close to him.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: You don’t have any more Arab guys to follow their guys.

dialogues.speaker: HOLIDAY
dialogues.text: ... Right. FERRIS steps away, controls his temper, turns back.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: We need human surveillance -- loaners from Jordanian secret service.

dialogues.speaker: HOLIDAY
dialogues.text: Young man, let’s have a chat. FERRIS looks at him interestedly. A “chat”? Certainly.

dialogues.speaker: HOLIDAY
dialogues.text: Skip, get out. SKIP goes out and looks back in through the glass wall.

dialogues.speaker: HOLIDAY
dialogues.text: I am in receipt of a directive which tells me to make myself useful to you in any way you request or require. But my feeling is that to involve the Jordanian secret service is a break of operational integrity. FERRIS nods as if taking it onboard. Then:

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: I know about Jordanian intelligence. They’re better than we are. You had plenty of time to get on the same page and you are not on it. What I need you to do now, sir, is to leave the Operations Room and hand your staff over to me. (as Holiday stares at him) I’‘1l have the Marines remove you. Do you have to read the ‘directive’ again, Mr. Holiday?

dialogues.speaker: HOLIDAY
dialogues.text: We’ve all watched your rise in the Near East Division. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HOLIDAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’1ll see you on your way down. You and Hoffman both.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: When I hit bottom, you’1ll probably have the best seat in the house. HOLIDAY regards Ferris a moment, then goes. FERRIS shuts the glass door and we see Holiday looking through it as if he’s just thought of something to say. He goes. FERRIS motions to SKIP, who enters the room.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: I need some coffee and I need a full staff meeting in fifteen minutes.

dialogues.speaker: SKIP
dialogues.text: To be fair to Mr. Holiday, Mr. Ferris, Mr. Hoffman didn’t tell us this was such a big deal.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Ed Hoffman is the head of the Middle East Division, but still doesn’t know shit until he steals it from the guy who does. Don’t be such a fucking ingenue. Get me an appointment with Hani Salaam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A complex flying the black flag of the Moukhabarat, with Arabic script reading “Justice Has Come.” INT. HANI’S ROOMS - DAY 68 The long room is decorated with portraits of Jordan's king and his father. HANI is cool. Lustrous black hair. Bit of gray in his mustache. Beautiful tailoring, polished shoes. He’s Chief of Jordan’s GID -- General Intelligence Directorate. An ormolu clock ticks.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Hani Pasha.

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: That is an Ottoman term.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: But I’ve heard you like it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: How do you like Jordan?

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: It is far from Damascus. Hani smiles and pours FERRIS a tea.

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: You are smarter than the Americans who are usually sent to Amman. (FERRIS bristling slightly) I knew that, of course, before you came... (hands Ferris the tea) Welcome to Jordan. A ‘promising’ country, you will find. As reliable as what Edward would call a ‘towelhead monarchy’ can be. And what have you heard about this building? (NOTE -- Let’s remember about FERRIS that he’s on his first big job with people of this caliber: but he’s got balls.)

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: I’ve heard they call it the fingernail factory. (as Hani laughs out loud) No one who knows you calls it that, certainly.

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: You know, people are foolish. Torture doesn’t work. Under torture any man will say any thing to make the pain stop. You know this from experience, I am sure. And HANI is sure. He’s not using a turn of phrase. FERRIS doesn't answer. Thinking about things he’s done. Things we know about. Things we don’t. They gravitate to the window where Hani sips his tea, and:

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: On a clear night you can see Jerusalem.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: And how do you feel about that? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 68 A long beat, and Hani refusing to give his opinion of Israel:

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: On a clear night, you can see Jerusalem. (turning more cheerfully) Here in Jordan we are caught between Iraq and a hard place. (a beat) To the fundamentalists I am myself an enemy. Perhaps the worst. (raises palms) ) ‘Take not the Jews and Christians as allies...’ Do you know it, Mister Ferris?

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: (in Arabic) ‘,.. if any of you take them as allies, then surely he is one of them.’ (back to English) 5:51. So, we’re together, Hani Pasha, in the House of War.

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: The Dar al’ Harb. (a beat) Very good. You know we are at war.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: I am here to win the war, Hani Pasha.

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: How shall we begin, with such an immodest plan. Silence. FERRIS commits.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: There’s a large Al-Saleem safehouse and training cell in Amman. I need your help with surveillance. If Hani is surprised, he doesn’t show it. will learn, never gives away anything... Hani, Ferris (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 68 69 CHATTER 9/21/07 -- PINK 36.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: This is what we know so far. He takes a FILE out of his case and puts it on Hani’s desk. Hani looks at it, then at Ferris.

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: This is unusual. Your Ed Hoffman would rather have less information than share what he has with me.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: I’m in Aamman now. It’s not Ed Hoffman. It’s not my predecessor. It’s me. HANI appraises FERRIS. Slowly:

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: I have one rule, my dear, if we are to cooperate: Never lie to me. FERRIS nods, but HANI, wanting more assurance, stares into his face:

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: Never -- lie -- to me. FERRIS nods again, gravely. He hears him.

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: You will have your agents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FERRIS, sitting in a ratty vehicle at an edge of the marketplace, eating food from a stall, bits of fish and rice with a wooden paddle, stares through sunglasses at: THE SAFEHOUSE: three stories of cinder-block in a row of other houses. A woman in a black headscarf hangs laundry on the roof. SKIP comes through the crowd, gets into the car.

dialogues.speaker: SKIP
dialogues.text: I’m not sure about this GID surveillance. I don’t see any of Hani’s guys.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Those two, selling radios. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 69 70 CHATTER 9/21/07 -- PINK 37.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: SKIP looks and sees: two JORDANIAN GUYS selling boxed cheap radios off the back of a truck. They have a good position from which to observe the house.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: There are at least four more moving around as customers in the bazaar, and there’s one in the cafe. (sees something else) What the fuck is this... A JIHADIST sits down at a cafe table, orders coffee and opens a paperback. Instantly a young Palestinian man, ZAYED IBISHI, sits down with him, begins speaking to him earnestly... THE JIHADIST looks confused, alarmed, gets to his feet. As ZAYED IBISHI implores him to sit and as we are on Zayed:

dialogues.speaker: SKIP
dialogues.text: That’s one of our guys.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: What do you mean one of our guys?

dialogues.speaker: SKIP
dialogues.text: A station asset. Zayed Ibishi. He’s one of our contacts in the Palestinian camps. ZAYED follows the JIHADIST through the crowd and the JIHADIST is terrified, anxious to lose him: this is a security breach!

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch! Fucking Hoffman. FERRIS leaps from the car and follows as fast as he can without being noticed. The JIHADIST punches ZAYED, knocking him down, and runs out of the square, going for the safehouse by a back route.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOFFMAN, headset on, turns from a live video of the market square and says very casually to no one:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The back streets get “back street” very quickly... Music from houses. Barking dogs. Boys kicking a soccer ball down the alley. Ferris gains on the Jihadist, who trots around a corner. FERRIS turns the corner and... is cut at with a knife -- his shirt slashed open.

dialogues.speaker: JIHADIST
dialogues.text: (in Arabic) Help! Help me! FERRIS tries to shush him, calm him down, though in truth he did come to kill him. A woman in a headscarf looks out her doorway. A man in a singlet comes chewing to a window. Ferris with regret but in two moves disarms the JIHADIST, and then in a third move kills him with his own knife as the WOMAN watches open-mouthed. FERRIS quickly takes the dead man’s papers and wallet. BOYS gather at the end of the alley. FERRIS, trapped, sees a wall with broken glass embedded on top and goes over it, cutting his hands, drops into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FERRIS is rushed by two savage dogs, big ones, garbage eaters. The only way out is back the way he came, over the wall, if he can make it in time. He jumps up, grabbing hold of the broken glass atop the wall as the dogs clamp onto his ankles and feet. He kicks them free, drops back down --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FERRIS hurries past the dead Jihadist, emerges onto another street, limping along outlandishly, bleeding. No one touches him. Into his cell --

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Get me now... get me now... behind the mosque... fuckin’ diseased dogs. As we begin to hear Jordanian police sirens -- We see MARWAN, with a high-powered rifle, retire from a roof parapet.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 73A
dialogues.text: 74 CHATTER 9/21/07 -- PINK 39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FERRIS is sitting in a hospital smock on a paper-covered exam table. The EMBASSY DOCTOR finishes a quick exam.

dialogues.speaker: EMBASSY DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Let’s get you cleaned up and jabbed. The rabies situation around here is no joke. FERRIS barely nods, sits, consumed with hatred for Hoffman and regret for what he has done. He looks around the clinic: Bright “Medical” cartoons for the American legation’s children. The food groups, etc. He barely notices a new presence in the room though we see details of AISHA'S hand-washing. AN ORDERLY comes in with RABIES VACCINE which is set on a counter. Cartons with French markings. Maybe just off a courier. FERRIS is aware of being touched, his wounds washed, and iodined. Almost like an autistic he manages to look up at:

dialogues.speaker: EXTRAORDINARY EYES
dialogues.text: above a pale blue disposable medical mask. The eyes swerve at him: look back at his wounds. She looks at other more recent wounds, burns, shrapnel: inventorying them. She turns over his hands and looks at the ripped palms and than at Ferris’ eyes.

dialogues.speaker: AISHA
dialogues.text: (in Arabic) These are not bite wounds. FERRIS of course cannot answer. There is a murder being looked at by Jordanian police.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: (in Arabic) No. She’s not going to get anything else out of him. She takes one of his hands and begins cleaning the cuts with antiseptic pads...

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: You're Iranian. EYES. No answer. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 74 CHATTER 9/21/07 -- PINK 40.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: (embarrassed and surprised that he nearly began a conversation) Your accent... AISHA opens the carton, gets an ampule, prepares an injection... and turns with a giant needle.

dialogues.speaker: AISHA
dialogues.text: I was Iranian. I live now in Amman. After a moment in which she seems to be measuring the depth of his personal pain, she stabs the needle into his stomach. With the needle still in:

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: ‘A Persian Heaven's easily made -- ‘Tis but black eyes and lemonade.’ AISHA seems to smile.

dialogues.speaker: AISHA
dialogues.text: That’s Byron... Are you a Romantic traveler?

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: There are a lot of things I was, that I’m not, anymore. Her EYES. She disposes of the needle. A bit discomfited:

dialogues.speaker: AISHA
dialogues.text: The doctor told you this is the first... are you listening? Of five injections you'll need over the next month. You will come here.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: We're done?

dialogues.speaker: AISHA
dialogues.text: Done. And that’s it. She goes through the hanging curtains, never having removed her mask. FERRIS, noticing his wedding ring, regretting that he had it on, reaches for his clothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 75 76 CHATTER 9/21/07 -- PINK 4l.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FERRIS, dressed, moves down a little hallway, and hearing running water, glances through a door and sees: AISHA, washing her hands. She has removed her mask. They look at each other. She gets it. He gets it.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: (in Arabic) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: AISHA
dialogues.text: (in Arabic) You are welcome. FERRIS lingers. But if there was ever a time to blow a moment to talk to a woman, this is it. He limps on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A phone line holding. SKIP gives a sign through the glass wall and FERRIS grabs up the handset.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: (viciously) You fucking cocksucker. I can’t run an operation with you running a side operation that fucks up mine. You want me to run Amman, I run Amman. I have made promises to Hani Salaam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOFFMAN, somewhat distracted, dropping his son off at preschool, eyeing the other kids’ mothers.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Promises... What’s your point? (off, to his son) Bye, bye. Say bye, bye --

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: My ‘point’ is, having met Hani, I can tell you we can’t do this kind of thing -- we have to respect him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 76 77 CHATTER 9/21/07 -- PINK 42.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: I respect him. Hani’s the best liar I've ever met -- plays a good game of tennis -- and he can drink like a regular white man. I respect the shit out of Hani.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: We can’t ask him for his help and then fuck everything up putting your guys where they don’t belong. The other embassy guys present glance at each other; no one talks to Ed Hoffman this way.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: If you fuck around, you will blow Amman, these motherfuckers will vacate their only known safehouse, and we will never see them again, Ed. Ever.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: You know me. I like to run Plan A and Plan B simultaneously. Just trying to back you up, buddy. It’s a dangerous world.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Don’t. I don’t need it.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Whatever. SKIP, on another phone, mouths, “Hani.”

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Now I’ve got to talk to Hani. Fuck you. FERRIS presses a button on the embassy phone. ED HOFFMAN looks at the phone in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANI and FERRIS are walking along a basement corridor.

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: The safehouse is still there. As for the man you killed... FERRIS looks at Hani. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: If you had not killed him, Marwan would have. You were right. You made a good decision. Listen to your ustaaz Hani. The jihadists believe it was a robbery. There are many robberies in that district. You are very clever, my dear.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Hoffman can’t help himself...

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: I have spoken to Edward, very sharply. Now, we will explain the King’s espionage laws to Mr. Hoffman’s agent. THROUGH A WINDOW AT GID: we and FERRIS see ZAYED IBISHI waiting terrified in a cell. JZAYED’s PANTS are pulled down and his wrists are cuffed to a table. MARWAN bends a RATTAN to prepare it, breaking it into sharp crackling strips.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: I thought you didn’t believe in torture, Hani Pasha.

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: This is punishment, my dear. An entirely different matter. Tell Edward what you have seen. MARWAN starts in with a hundred of the best. INT. FERRIS’ APARTMENT (AMMAN) - NIGHT TIA FERRIS is in bed, his leg iced. He uses the remote to switch off the TV, the lights. Then his silenced cell phone lights up. He looks at the caller ID, hesitates, then opens it. No sound other than heavy breathing.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Gretchen... what do you want?

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I want you to fuck me.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: (impressed) From here? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You can always try, honey... I am so, fucking, hot...

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: This phone is tapped, Gretchen. Why don’t you say hello to Ed Hoffman, the Moukhbaharat, the Mossad...

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I don’t care... let them listen. I’m taking my panties off now...

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Well, let your lawyer wear them on his head at his next court appearance.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Don’t embarrass me, Roger.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Look, I really admire what you've done with yourself in DC, at State... your whole deal in Washington... I just don’t want any part of it.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I don’t want a divorce. I just want a change...

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: I want a change, too. I want to be the guy with a divorce. You don’t love me, I don’t love you... You just don’t want to bother looking for another husband. Sorry. He hangs up. EXT. AMSTERDAM —- DAY 78 A CHINESE TOURIST, digital camera in hand, moves among the crowds at ALBERT CUYP MARKET. He pauses at a souvenir stand. Regards a neat row of replicas of windmills in ascending size. Picks one up and turns it over to check the price and discuss it with his WIFE. He sets it back down and moves with his wife toward a more crowded stall selling knock-off leather goods. Stares blankly at the merchandise. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As he takes out a handkerchief and wipes his brow, the sounds all around him begin to fade. Then silence. And a blast of white light as he disappears -- INT. HANI’S APARTMENT — (AMMAN) - MORNING 79 A bedroom, where HANI watches TV as his wife brushes her teeth in the bathroom. The TV shows images of the Amsterdam bombing captured by security cameras... INT. FERRIS’ APARTMENT (AMMAN) - MORNING 80 PULL BACK to reveal we are in ANOTHER APARTMENT. FERRIS sits on the edge of his bed, drink in hand, ice on his leg... the same news report on TV...

dialogues.speaker: THE REPORT 81
dialogues.text: cuts to the aftermath of the bombing: Images of bloodied tourists carried to ambulances, sitting stunned on curbs, zipped into body bags. And -- INT. AL-SALEEM’S APARTMENT (ENGLAND) - DAY 82 We are in a middle-class apartment, where AL-SALEEM sits on a couch with a napping child, hand resting protectively on the child’s side, watching the same news report on a TV. Behind him, his wife clears plates from the dinner table... EXT. FERRIS’ APARTMENT (AMMAN) - DAY 82A As FERRIS emerges from the front door, sunglasses on... Hani’s bodyguard, MARWAN (a street thug), holds open the back door of a black Mercedes. Three more just like it are lined up and idling. FERRIS looks into Hani’s car.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: Fishing. HANI is immaculate in a black suit.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: I see you’re dressed for it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: Get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four black Mercedes scream across the desert. There’s no water for hundreds of miles.

dialogues.speaker: 82A
dialogues.text: 83 84 85 HANI is in the back with FERRIS. MARWAN sits in front with the driver.

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: Since no credit was claimed in Amsterdam, we know it was Al- Saleem. That’s his signature. Anonymity. We -- may I say ‘we’? --

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: You may. As long as we’re not including Hoffman --

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: -- need a man inside the Amman cell.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: (looking at him) We do.

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: We shall have the man we need. Ferris’ look says to him, “seriously?” Hani nods.

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: You gave me one.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: (genuinely curious) How? 85A FLASHBACK —- THE PHOTO OF KARAMI

dialogues.speaker: 85A
dialogues.text: in Hani’s office, in Hani’s hands. And Ferris watching him look at it...  86 87 88 CHATTER 9/21/07 -- PINK 47.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: KARAMI entering the back room of a cafe through a beaded curtain, is seized violently.

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: I’ve known Mustafa Karami since he was a teenager selling stolen boomboxes from the back of a truck. Now he’s AQ. In my country. Hani lights a Sherman with a beautiful gold lighter etched with swords and his initials.

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: Watch and learn, my dear. We see the eyes of HANI’S DRIVER glance up in the rearview mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSTAFA KARAMI, a black bag over his head, kneels in the dust, hands tied, while around him stand GID men, talking, smoking. Nearby is an SUV with an old bicycle on top. HANI’S CARAVAN OF MERCEDES move into a half circle, dust blowing, making a little amphitheater. Hani and Ferris and security men get out, all in sunglasses. HANI's fine SHOES step through the sand towards KARAMI. FERRIS watches as he crouches before the blindfolded man. In Arabic, subtitled:

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: Hello, Mustafa, my friend. It’s me. God is great.

dialogues.speaker: KARAMI
dialogues.text: What do you want! Silence.

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: You did not think to tell Hani Salaam that you are a jihadist? Silence. KARAMI is terrified. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: You have become a religious man. A pious man. No longer a thief. You had bad luck in the world. It is so with many religious. Or perhaps you are still not so pious. But you still love your mother... MARWAN cuts the bonds on KARAMI’S WRISTS. A significant act. The trembling hands, freed. HANI crouches, and gently:

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: I have someone who wants to talk to you. Take this phone. Please. It is only a phone. Take it. (puts it in Karami’s hand) Take the phone and talk to your mother. I will dial the phone. Your mother has a new telephone number, in her new apartment. KARAMI takes the phone. HANI walks back to Ferris. While KARAMI talks on the cell in the middle distance: FERRIS is

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: His mother was in the Palestinian camps. Now she has a fine apartment. A garden... beginning to smile.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Which Karami bought her?

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: She will tell him that she is proud of him. That she always knew he would be a success, even as a little boy in the refugee camps. And now he has sent her money, she is glad he is no longer mixed up with the radicals. FERRIS grins. We can tinnily hear KARAMI’S MOTHER, a voluble woman, going on and on, not realizing that her son is in the desert with a bag on his head.

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: She can sit in a chair and watch the sun set over the hills. She has a refrigerator, a couch. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Even a television set. He is a great son, thanks to God. KARAMI is crying.

dialogues.speaker: KARAMI
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Mother, goodbye. Hands over the phone to a GID man, who turns it off. HANI reapproaches him, gesturing to a GID MAN who brings Hani a folding chair, swats dust off of it with a handkerchief. Hani sits elegantly. Subtitles:

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: You are God’s blessing to your mother, Mustafa. You did none of those things for her. But you should have. A mother, and that she should live in peace, is more important than anything they have told you. In the future you will be better. We have given her many gifts and we have told her these gifts come from her son. This is a hasanna we have done. A good deed. THE BAG is removed from KARAMI’S head.

dialogues.speaker: KARAMI
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do?

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: Continue your life! Be a good Muslim! Do not be detected as my friend. You know what happens to those who are detected.

dialogues.speaker: KARAMI
dialogues.text: And what else?

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: We will think of it in time. Continue your life, with your brothers in Al Quaeda. We will devise a way to talk. MUSTAFA embraces HANI’s legs.

dialogues.speaker: KARAMI
dialogues.text: Thanks be to God. HANI raises KARAMI to his feet and kisses both cheeks. FERRIS watches: a masterpiece. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: THE GID THUGS put the shaking KARAMI back in the SUV with the bike tied to the top. Speed off.

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: So we throw him back in the sea to swim where he naturally swims and learn what he naturally learns, and see how long he remembers my benevolence.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: And if he forgets?

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: If he forgets, I remind him I hold the power of life and death over him. Anytime I wish I can let them know he works for me. HANI looks around at his guys.

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: Did we bring anything to eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hipster place. Electroclash music pounding at the walls from inside, spilling out with German post-punks onto the sidewalk. A CAR parked nearby. Two shaven Turks in sunglasses, young men who could easily be from the club. But, as they get out of the car we see one has wet his pants. The other one takes out a cell phone as they come past the club. When they reach the corner he consults numbers scribbled on a piece of paper and presses them into the phone... but nothing happens. He tries again... They start back toward the club and the van, the Turk looking at the single reception bar on his phone as he keeps pressing the “resend button.” Suddenly, he gets 4 bars and the car detonates -- and -- A CCTV camera’s view of the huge explosion whites out, then goes to black... EXT./INT. FERRIS’ APARTMENT (AMMAN) - NIGHT 90 FERRIS, back from work at the embassy (different clothes from his excursion with HANI -- we may want to insert a bit of Ferris watching the bombing at work) climbs from his car and heads for his apartment, phone earpiece in -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So tell me about Karami.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hani’s guy. Karami. What do you think I do in my spare time, play tennis? I'm in the CIA. I am the CIA. Fucking Salaam-Salaam Amateur Hour is over. Europe’s having the shit blown out of it. FERRIS unlocks the outside gate of his building and climbs interior stairs.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: It’s not going to happen, Ed.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yes, it is. You know why? Because otherwise I’1ll be unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: You’1l be unhappy and he’1l say, Ma’alesh.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What’s that mean?

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Too fuckin’ bad.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There’s a bomb every two days. We need results now.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: You need the appearance of results.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yes Ido. Yes I do. Let’s live in the real world and say yes I do. What is this? Decaf? Are you kidding me? FERRIS comes down the corridor past other apartment doors.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Hani doesn’t trust you. Arabs help you because they trust you. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 90 91 CHATTER 9/21/07 -- PINK 52.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They’1l do everything for a friend and nothing for someone who treats them with disrespect.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What are you, moving here? I don’t care about towelhead insecurity issues.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Who do you have on Hani’s team, Ed?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Ma’alesh. Who pays the heating bills for Jordanian Intelligence? FERRIS finds his apartment door open a crack, and HOFFMAN'S voice splitting into two voices out of sync --

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We'll let Hani do his bit. I just want to give him a little help. He’ll thank me for it in the long run. FERRIS finds HOFFMAN standing in his kitchen, phone in one hand, empty French press carafe in the other.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Good. You’re home. Here. Make some coffee. You ought to have a Mr. Coffee like a human being. He hands FERRIS the carafe and wanders into the other room to switch on the news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ARMORED US EMBASSY CAR is waved onto the complex. Inside, in back, Hoffman drinks from a travel cup --

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: In the words of the great Sam Snead, ‘If you’re not thinking about pussy, you’re just not concentrating.’ (grins and adds) ‘My dear.’ +e  92 CHATTER 9/21/07 -- PINK 53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOFFMAN, FERRIS, HANI, the staring MARWAN and tea service.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: I want a piece of the guy you’ve got in the Amman cell. HANI looks at FERRIS. Then back at HOFFMAN.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: To clear the young man, here, he told me zip. The jihadists don’t use cell phones, Hani. You do. Smiles.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Don’t say no before I say anything. Let me say what I have to say. Hani says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Thank you. You have done a hell of a job developing this guy, Kitami, Kabami...

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: Karami.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: It’s just nifty. But I’m frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: Why are you frustrated, Edward?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: I’m frustrated because you put me in a pickle, Hani. There are guys out there riding the Milan sleeper with polonium in a fucking coffee can. There’s a bomb every other goddamn day. There is urgency. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: Urgency does not call for changing methods which work, for methods which do not work.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Who do you think pays the bills here, Hani? I’d hate to have the President call the King.

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: In matters of intelligence, you are speaking to the King. Edward.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: I still want some control. Asa special favor to the United States.

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: You can’t have it. I’m sorry. I could tell you we will run him jointly, but it wouldn’t be the truth. Real intelligence operations stay secret forever. You Americans cannot understand that. You are incapable of secrecy, because you are a democracy. I know my business and have never failed you in the past. Have I.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: No, this is the first time. Ferris watches them, and the impasse between them. Is the conversation over, or only about to get tougher...

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: Karami is my asset, Edward. I intend to keep him that way.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: (having had enough) You think you’re the only guy who knows anything and that is not true, Hani. Your boy Karami? He has a cousin who’s up in France on a Saudi passport, right now. I need to know what he’s doing there before he makes Paris uninhabitable for the next five hundred fucking years. And maybe Karami knows. Hence, my ‘urgency.’ (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a  92 CHATTER 9/21/07 -- PINK 54A.

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: You’re missing the point. Karami would not know where he is. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 92 CHATTER 9/21/07 -- PINK 55.

dialogues.speaker: HANI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It is not the way the organization operates. You care about the French?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Not necessarily, but I wouldn’t mind taking the kids there without wearing a radiation suit.

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: I‘1l ask him what he knows -- when it is time. I agree, Ed, to ask him your superfluous question. Are you happy? angry, takes a file from his briefcase. Sets a picture down on the table: An Arab man in a knitted prayer cap.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: You may have invented algebra but we're the ones figured out what the fuck to do with it. Know what this is?

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: It’s a recent photograph of Al-Saleem. FERRIS looks at the picture then at HOFFMAN.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: From a fake Yemeni passport. He got in and out of the UK on that. I’m sure he’s got another one now, but you didn’t have that, did you. He grins smugly at Hani, who just calmly sips his tea.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Well, you keep it, Hani. Because we are partners. I keep my side of the bargain. Now, you give me Karami.

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: Ma’alesh. FERRIS looks at Ed.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Too fuckin’ bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the back of the car, HOFFMAN slips his sunglasses on.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Still thinking about pussy, Ed?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Don’t be a smart ass. I'm not through. Hani's bright but he's also arrogant and that's going to be his undoing.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: You're talking about him.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
