dialogues.text: I could have used new intel on al-Saleen too, Ed. You’re holding back from me? What else are you holding back?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: More than I told him, I'11l tell you that. We know where al-Saleen is from, for one thing. He’s a Syrian, from Hama. His real name, not that he’s used it for years, is Karim Al-Shams -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AL-SALEEM’S FACE - DAY Somewhere -- as it rises up from prayer. As he bows a second time, we begin to PULL BACK, revealing other praying men on either side of him.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: His family was killed by Hafez Assad. He went to live in Saudi Arabia. He studied engineering and physics in Riyadh, then here in Amman, post-graduate at the University of North Carolina... man was a Tarheel... STILL PULLING BACK REVEALS Al-Saleem to be among a thousand devout men praying on the floor of a huge mosque... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH HH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 94 CHATTER 9/21/07 -- PINK 57.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And, we found documents in Afghanistan that show he experimented in considerable detail with nuclear and biological devices, so he is not fucking around. I’m hearing now he’s in Italy. IT ISN'T ITALY -- it’s closer than Italy -- and we can see that as AL-SALEEM and the hundreds of other men file out of the mosque and into the street, many of them -- but not AL-SALEEM -- resuming their lives on cell phones.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Ed?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Don’t do anything about Karami. Don’t try to flip him. Hani will throw me out of the country. Nothing from HOFFMAN. FERRIS waits. Eventually -

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Fine. Now that I'm sensitive to the situation. But listen to me. Because I can see what's developing between you two love birds: You cannot trust him. Hoffman is serious and waits for a nod from Ferris.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Now can we get drunk so I can sleep on the flight back? I have to take the kids to “The Lion King”. Don’t ever have kids. I’m serious. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a  94 95 96 CHATTER 9/21/07 -- PINK 58.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Don’t touch Karami, Ed.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSTAFA KARAMI is heading somewhere, presumably away from the safehouse. As he enters a narrow alley: Watching him is SKIP, sitting behind the wheel of a mud- caked car, cord dangling from his ear.

dialogues.speaker: SKIP
dialogues.text: All right, here we go. Take him. As Karami sees four men step out of doorways in front of him, Skip’s car screeches INTO VIEW behind, blocking his exit.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SOCCER FIELD
dialogues.text: A JIHADIST stops playing football and stares towards the alley. He looks confused, and then he backs up, and then he runs towards the safehouse visible in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The relative quiet of the clinic. Aisha preparing Ferris’ second rabies injection. A CHAPERONE watches from nearby.

dialogues.speaker: AISHA
dialogues.text: I think I told you you could get this at any clinic.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: You did. But when you find a good doctor, you don’t change. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She stabs CHATTER 9/21/07 -- PINK 59. 96

dialogues.speaker: AISHA
dialogues.text: I’m not a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: (in Arabic) Nurse, doctor, accountant, imam, same thing.

dialogues.speaker: AISHA
dialogues.text: Wife.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Am I wearing a ring?

dialogues.speaker: AISHA
dialogues.text: No. But you were last week. (a beat) Are you a bad husband?

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: I’m a bad husband and she’s a bad wife. We deserved each other, but it’s over now.

dialogues.speaker: AISHA
dialogues.text: Now you’re looking for something else. Something as different from her as you can find. Something impossible maybe. him with the needle. Drops it in the “sharps” bin. Pulls off her latex gloves and throws them away.

dialogues.speaker: AISHA
dialogues.text: We’re done.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: ‘Til next week.

dialogues.speaker: AISHA
dialogues.text: If you like.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: I'd like if it was maybe sooner than that. Maybe later today. (in Arabic) Unless that would make you uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: AISHA
dialogues.text: I think it would make you uncomfortable more than me.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: I doubt that. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AISHA
dialogues.text: I don’t.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ferris is walking with Aisha down a narrow street that leads to a slum. A tinny radio somewhere plays Arabic music. Young angry men slouch in doorways, staring at them. Aisha seems to enjoy his unease. In Arabic --

dialogues.speaker: AISHA
dialogues.text: Was I right?

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: When I arrived in Amman they advised me where not to go. This was one of them.

dialogues.speaker: AISHA
dialogues.text: I could have told you this is where I was going, if you’d asked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An outdoor clinic that makes Aisha’s other clinic look like Cedars. As she makes her rounds, attending to the sick, Ferris -- very much aware that everyone is aware of, and hates him -- waits, smokes. One of the young, unemployed men leaning against a wall covered with peeling posters of Arafat and anti-American graffiti, says in Arabic loud enough for Ferris to hear, “Who's the Jew?” Ferris ignores them as best he can, watches as an Arab man in a robe (HIJAZI, we will come to know later) talks with Aisha and gives her an envelope of cash...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAFE OWNER comes out to where Ferris and Aisha are sitting, wiping his hands on a towel, humble, terrified.

dialogues.speaker: AISHA
dialogues.text: (in Arabic) Two teas, Mohammed. Thank you. The cafe owner nods but doesn’t leave. He seems unable to believe she has brought this man who could only be an American spy into his place, endangering him. Arabic: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 99 CHATTER 9/21/07 -- PINK 61.

dialogues.speaker: AISHA
dialogues.text: (meaning “go”) Thank you. The cafe owner leaves them. FERRIS opens a folding knife under the cheap tablecloth, lays it on his lap, and smiles with a little difficulty at Aisha.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: If you're trying to find out how far I’ll go to express my interest I think you have the answer.

dialogues.speaker: AISHA
dialogues.text: Do I? What else are you supposed to do at this point? Leave here alone? You're safer with me and you know it. Though there’s only so much I can do to protect you. Their hatred of you is intense. Everyone -- over their dominoes and cards and nargila smoke -- is staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: AISHA
dialogues.text: I don’t hate you. Unless I should. Should I?

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: What are you asking?

dialogues.speaker: AISHA
dialogues.text: I’m asking what you do here. In Amman.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Political Counselor.

dialogues.speaker: AISHA
dialogues.text: That’s sufficiently vague. (a beat) I have a thing to tell you. An important one. A man is not his job. He wonders what she is trying to tell him. Her English fails her...

dialogues.speaker: AISHA
dialogues.text: He is... apart from his job. The man.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Haven't tried that, recently. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AISHA
dialogues.text: I just want you to know... my feel -.. My understand... My understanding. Of you. They regard each other. The nervous cafe owner returns, his hands shaking as he sets the tea glasses down.

dialogues.speaker: AISHA
dialogues.text: We are friends. We may talk again. She sips her tea. And for Ferris it’s out of this world different from anything in his life to date.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: (in Arabic) When you wish. And with your permission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FERRIS escorts AISHA home -- or rather she, him. YOUNG ARAB MEN watch them from a dark storefront. Arabic music plays from an open window. This is a dangerous place, too.

dialogues.speaker: AISHA
dialogues.text: My apartment’s just around the corner. Thank you for walking me back. As they turn the corner, MARWAN and TWO OTHER GID MEN appear in front of them. The GID MEN are the same who were watching SKIP try to kidnap Karami. All in Arabic:

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Marwan... salaam.

dialogues.speaker: MARWAN
dialogues.text: Come.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: I have to escort my friend home. AISHA already has her keys out.

dialogues.speaker: AISHA
dialogues.text: It's just there.

dialogues.speaker: MARWAN
dialogues.text: With permission, Miss. Meaning, “Leave us.” Aisha regards FERRIS. In English: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: It’s all right. They’re friends of mine. Now it’s AISHA who’s scared, more for herself than him.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: It’s fine. She crosses the street and unlocks the gate to her building. MARWAN and the GID MEN escort FERRIS toward a parked car.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: What is it? What’s wrong? Aisha glances back as they usher FERRIS into the back of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It enters the square where the safehouse used to be. MARWAN grabs FERRIS by the hair and turns his face to the window so that he can see... The SAFEHOUSE burning. FIRE TRUCKS. Water being sprayed on the burning building. FERRIS closes his eyes. Everything is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SEAGULLS and VULTURES tear at black plastic bags and rubbish. Fires burn here and there. Everything you can think of has been discarded. FERRIS is pulled out of the GID car, and pushed towards HANI, who looks especially elegant, set against the garbage dump.

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: Marwan showed you the burning house? (as Ferris nods) Do you know what happened?

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: I have absolutely no idea. Hani studies Ferris. Then:

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: You could've said yes or no. Simply that. When a man says more than yes or no, I wonder. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 102 CHATTER 9/21/07 -- PINK 64.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: I don’t know what (happened) --

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: We had the advantage. That house could have led us to Al-Saleem. Now it’s gone. And everything in it.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Hani. I...

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: I told you, never lie to me.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: I’m not lying. Hani studies him again. Then glances to Marwan who signals to the other men. A figure is dragged from a car and stood before Hani and Ferris, the sack pulled from his head. It’s SKIP. Terrified. To Ferris:

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: You didn’t know -- that after all I said to you -- and Edward -- this man tried to take Karami.

dialogues.speaker: SKIP
dialogues.text: He didn’t (know) -- Hani backhands SKIP so fast and hard, it chokes his last word and almost knocks him from his feet.

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: (calmly, to SKIP) When I speak to you, I’1l look at you. I’m talking to Mr. Ferris now. (to Ferris) In as few words as possible... did you know?

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: No. Hani studies Ferris...

dialogues.speaker: HANI
dialogues.text: I don’t believe you. Leave Jordan. Hani calmly walks to his car and climbs in. Marwan and the other GID men follow. The cars drive off leaving Ferris and SKIP alone in the dump. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Now Ferris regards SKIP with as much menace as Hani did.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Let’s get real, man. Let’s... Obviously, I have been a douche. We have things to straighten up... but a direct order, man, is a direct order. FERRIS walks away through the garbage dump without untying SKIP. Walking angrily, purposefully.

dialogues.speaker: SKIP
dialogues.text: Ferris! FERRIS keeps walking. VULTURES hop closer to SKIP.

dialogues.speaker: SKIP
dialogues.text: Ferris! Ferris!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A deserted outdoor concert amphitheater. Wet folding chairs in disarray. HOFFMAN looks awful, relatively, and FERRIS is in a rage.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: If you're keeping all the cards to your chest, how do you expect me to function? All he asked was patience and you couldn't do it. You were impatient and greedy and you fucked it up. I thought Hani was going to kill me.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Naw, he likes you. He likes you. What’s he going to get over there better than you? You'll get back to Jordan before you know it. Back to that Jordanian piece of ass. FERRIS makes a move as if to hit HOFFMAN. HOFFMAN stumbles back onto the wet grass. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Ed, you’re an old fat fuck. I do this shit for a living. Go ona goddamned diet.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: What are we, in a school yard? HOFFMAN stands up.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Look, I did what I had to do. I don't have time for ‘patience, sidi, patience’ and sit around and eat fucking couscous. Hani’s interests extend no further than his little fiefdom. Mine are global. That said, I admit I should have told you what I was doing.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: No, what you should’ve done was not do it.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Ten years ago I could’ve beat the shit out of you.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Then you should have taken your shot back then. They take a moment to size each other up.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Somehow, we have to get our own guy inside Al-Saleem’s tent.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: We could penetrate every Salafi mosque in the world and never get to him. HOFFMAN knows it’s true.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: But he doesn’t know that. That we can’t do it. He doesn’t know how close or far we are. What’s true and what isn’t. We could make it appear there was another organization out there as deadly as his own. What would Al-Saleem do? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Rejoice. And/or be paranoid.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Exactly. Doesn’t matter which, he'd try to get in touch with them... but it would be us.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: It would be us... (a beat) We can’t do it out of Langley.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Oh no.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: You know, I am going to have to revise my opinion of you. I had no idea you were so devious. This puts you in a whole new category in Eddie Hoffman's book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FERRIS opens the door revealing a gorgeous woman dressed for a night out -- or in -- like the best Deborah Palfrey’s escort service has to offer. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: You called for someone?

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: You must have. Because I’m here. I’m Nicole. The woman lets herself in and goes straight to the mini- bar to make herself a drink.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Do you mind if I have a drink? It relaxes me. Which will relax you. Ferris closes the door but does not put out the “Do Not Disturb” sign. Comes back into the room.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: This is a nice place. We can have some fun here.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: I want this divorce.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Shhh. I don’t want to talk about that.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: We don’t have to talk about it. We just have to do it. She sips her drink. Sits on the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: No, let’s talk about it. Sit. She pats the cushion next to her. He knows better but sits there anyway. She touches his face and neck and says nothing. He pulls slightly away.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: You're right, there’s nothing to talk about. You don’t love me and I don’t love you.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Neither is true.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: What do we have. Nothing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: We have a marriage people dream about.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Marriage is about children -- and we don’t have that -- which makes ending it easy.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Marriage isn’t only about that. Her hand has moved down to his leg.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Gretchen --

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: My name is Nicole --

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Gretchen --

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: I don’t know what you think is wrong. I don’t think you know. You’re seeing someone? Fine.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: I’m not.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Marriage can work with that. She unzips his fly and slips her hand in.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: I need you. I need my husband. I need my husband, and you don’t touch me? Touch me. He doesn’t and she slaps him hard. Then coos:

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Touch me. She takes his hand. He allows her to put it under her short skirt. And as it’s happening, he hates, but can’t help, himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FERRIS drives himself through the Virginia countryside. INT. FERRIS’ CAR 105A FERRIS driving --INTERCUT w/ ATTORNEY

dialogues.speaker: ATTORNEY
dialogues.text: This is why you have a lawyer, you stupid idiot.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: It’s still over, Larry, it doesn’t matter.

dialogues.speaker: ATTORNEY
dialogues.text: It does matter. It doesn’t look good.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: And I don’t feel good about it. I got to go --

dialogues.speaker: ATTORNEY
dialogues.text: Don’t call her, don’t see her, don’t fuck her -- anymore.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: I told her on the way out the door we were still getting divorced.

dialogues.speaker: ATTORNEY
dialogues.text: How’d she take it? Instead of conveying the enormity of the answer, Ferris hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A modest house set in dark parkland by a horror-film lake. FERRIS parks next to an Audi, the only other car in sight. Climbs out and crunches across gravel to the porch. Looks through a window at sheeted furniture. He hears a creaking sound and follows it to the side porch where he finds a MAN in a wicker rocker, napping. A BlackBerry rests on a little table.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Garland? I’m Roger Ferris. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Garland glances over and regards Ferris. When he speaks it’s with a vague European accent, a bit effeminate:

dialogues.speaker: GARLAND, (MAN)
dialogues.text: Where’s Hoffman?

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: I don’t know. A Ben and Jerry's. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GARLAND
dialogues.text: He trusts you. (meaning, to send you here alone) I don’t trust him. Whenever you run an operation and don’t see Hoffman, it means he’s running another operation. The BlackBerry chimes softly. Garland glances at the incoming text message.

dialogues.speaker: GARLAND
dialogues.text: I’m tracking a cell in Syria. They were in Damascus last night. Today, Dayr-az-Zor, on their way to the Iraqi border. But something tells me they aren't going to make it to Husbaya. We have ninjas waiting.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Who do the ninjas work for?

dialogues.speaker: GARLAND
dialogues.text: Nobody. Fruit? Ferris isn’t sure what he means.

dialogues.speaker: GARLAND
dialogues.text: Do you want some fruit? An apple. Orange. Some berries.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: No, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bowl of fruit on an otherwise bare wood table.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Where is everyone?

dialogues.speaker: GARLAND
dialogues.text: I’m not sure what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: It's just you?

dialogues.speaker: GARLAND
dialogues.text: No. It’s me -- and you. Garland chooses a fat strawberry from a bowl. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 107 CHATTER 9/21/07 -- PINK 73.

dialogues.speaker: GARLAND
dialogues.text: You expected a war room? Flashing lights and people running through with clipboards? It’s all here -- (holds up BlackBerry) And here -- (a laptop) And here -- (his head) You’‘re sure you don’t want some (fruit).

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Positive. Eating his strawberry, Garland becomes momentarily distracted by a bird flying around the dusty space.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: I’m going to need some low-level AQ contacts. A lawyer. Some kind of Security Consultant. But first I need an Arab who travels a lot in the region. A businessman who fits the profile of jihadist without actually being a jihadist.

dialogues.speaker: GARLAND
dialogues.text: A straw man. Receiving money. Making plans. lLet’s start with him. GARLAND plops onto an Aeron chair, clicks a remote. As the BIRD flies across a plasma screen, a Powerpoint presentation comes up. Garland clicks through earnest middle-aged male Arab faces...

dialogues.speaker: GARLAND
dialogues.text: No... no... no... no... Maybe here’s your man. We see a passport photograph on the screen of a pious, somewhat bland zealot.

dialogues.speaker: GARLAND
dialogues.text: His name is Omar Sadiki. He's Jordanian. An architect. Most of his commissions come from Islamic charitable groups who also send money to jihadists. He’s got every jihadist signifier... Except he’s innocent. FERRIS steps up to the screen. Regarding the callus on the middle of Sadiki’s forehead. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: He touches his head to the ground five times a day... He believes in God.

dialogues.speaker: GARLAND
dialogues.text: I wonder what that’s like. So does Ferris probably. He hasn’t believed in anything since he was five.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: What makes you think he’1ll trade with an infidel like me?

dialogues.speaker: GARLAND
dialogues.text: (looks at Ferris like he must be daft) Money. INT. FERRIS’ DC HOTEL ROOM - DAY 107AA FERRIS cell phone rings. He answers.

dialogues.text: Look around at this restaurant, before you throw the glass. That's why I picked the restaurant. GRETCHEN sees the results: a career-ender. She smiles at a colleague.

dialogues.text: You don’t have the balls for this, Roger. You're not a killer. That’s always been me.

dialogues.text: I made those for you, you fucking bastard.

dialogues.text: This is a shopping center in Fahaneel in Kuwait... Offices in Amman... A dormitory for the College of Technology in Irbid... All uninspired but not terrible...

dialogues.text: Uh-huh... nice... but for our branch here in Dubai, we’re after something with more of a... Islamic ambiance.

dialogues.text: This is more like it.

dialogues.text: Mr. Sadiki, I know you must have a certain level of discomfort just sitting with a non-believer, what with all that’s going on. But let me assure you: I despise this horrible war. I’m a Democrat. Ferris makes a terrible smile.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Exactly as much as I tell you. Tony waits to hear it, but apparently he just did. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: I’m cool with that. I’m used to knowing nothing.

dialogues.text: Ferris has rejoined Sadiki as he finishes photographing the site.

dialogues.text: Sorry about that.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Useful friend. FERRIS pushes the photo back across to Hani --

dialogues.text: 125 CHATTER 9/21/07 -- PINK 91.

dialogues.text: You want the best...

dialogues.speaker: SADIKI
dialogues.text: Yes, we very much wish to... have the job. Perhaps a change or two is possible.

dialogues.speaker: FERRIS
dialogues.text: Well, give me your best price, close as you can to a 25 percent reduction.

dialogues.speaker: SADIKI
